computer.description:
The Kaypro Robie was presented at the Las Vegas Comdex in 1984. It was the first non-portable Kaypro machine.
Except from its strange case design, the main feature of the Robie was that it had two 2.6 Mb floppy drives. Apart from that, the motherboard was basically the same as the Kaypro 4, with a 300 baud modem, rough graphics, real-time clock, etc.
Thanks to LaVerne Kreklau for most of the pictures _______________________

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> RUNNING SYSTEM #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice that this Robie has a Kaypro II keyboard. <br><br> The Robie is running a graphic form of a clock, written in Microsoft BASIC.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> RUNNING SYSTEM #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The left floppy drive has been replaced with a Kodak drive. <br><br> The program displayed is what the Robie originally booted to. It's a program called "masmenu.com" and could be configured the way the user wanted by editing a file called "masmenu.txt".</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> General purpose serial port<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> Second serial port dedicated to a printer<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> Keyboard RJ11 connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> CRT brightness adjustment<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> Power switch, fuse ans socket<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> Cooling fan<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> Reset switch<br> <b><font color="blue">(8)</font></b> External modem RJ11 connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(9)</font></b> Parallel printer connector<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>LaVerne Kreklau</b> for most of the pictures</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR SIDE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Although Kaypro had a sales subsidiary in Europe, very few (maybe none) Robie were sold in Europe.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FLOPPY DRIVES</strong></font><br><blockquote>The high-density floppy drives offered a storage capacity never seen before on a 5.25" drive. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MASTER DISKETTE</strong></font><br><blockquote>In addition to the CP/M OS, the Master diskette held more than 10 various software. <br><br> About the diskettes to be used with the Robie, an addendum to the Robie manual specifies:<br><font color="#666666"> DISKETTES FOR YOUR KAYPRO 4X and ROBIE.<br><br> The diskettes used on your KAYPRO 4X or ROBIE are not the standard diskettes used on most other computers. The diskette drives are high density (they hold a lot more), and must be pur­chased pre-formatted. <br><br> When you buy high-density diskettes, be certain you get formatted 17-sector, 192 TPI diskettes. More than one diskette format is available, you MUST get 17-SECTOR, 192 TPI PRE-FORMATTED DISKETTES, others will not work. Brown Disk UHRII, or the Maxell equivalent, is the format to specify to your dealer. <br><br> The ROBIE and KAYPRO.4X can read diskettes written by other KAYPRO computers. .You can transfer files from standard KAYPRO diskettes to ROBIE diskettes, but it cannot write anything to these other diskettes.</font></blockquote>
